{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "So let's review our work on this set of systems, integrity, and come alive, and parliaments. And I think we are on a good track to be exploring deliberative democracy and argumentation theory. And also the principle that a formal system can never contain the proof of its own system, and how it might be something about how consciousness can never prove that consciousness is conscious, and how that might mean that maybe the fools errant to be doing what we're doing, or the possibility that integrity offers to say that consciousness can never come within its system, but from intersubjectivity, with good formal methods, we can say something real about something that is impossible to say something real about. And I'm also wondering how it might be connected to the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle. You can't measure something and know things accurately about it. The more you try to measure it, the more you mess with it, sort of thing. And I'm wondering if there's a relationship between integrity, what we're exploring, and these systems.", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T06:52:48.371118+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T06:52:48.371118+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_0000000049f06230ab35ae8ccc339d1c', 'size_bytes': 4354638, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 90.72}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 95.72969732400088}

{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T06:56:42.751964+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T06:56:42.751964+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_000000006ebc62309d1b9ee100a0fc72', 'size_bytes': 6146958, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 128.06}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 313.4730834189977}
{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Okay, so that sounds interesting, and I'm wondering, though, if it actually brings us closer to what we want to do in the end, bringing people closer together onto this idea that there is a shared reality. And it reminds me of this whole, like, Wu Wei thing, you know, this choiceless action. And I'm wondering if there's a reason that the kind of wise person doesn't even know they're acting is because they don't want to be measuring at all, they want to be leaving the thing to be doing a thing, and to be the doing that's doing, but to somehow not be at the same time. And what is that kind of, what is the thing that can do that? I guess, you know, in the Muslim tradition, it says that the heavens and the earth can't contain God, but the heart of a believing Muslim, like, what is it about belief? Is it about that sense of security that you get of just, like, everything is under the control of the most perfect, most merciful? I can relax. And you know, also, like, as long as I'm doing these things in this, you know, way, like, I got this covered, then maybe I can relax into what emerges from there, you know? Like, there are the bounds of God, and then go be free, you know? And I think there's something there about, like, the importance of constraints, and the importance of constraints in believing that it comes from a divine source. The difficult thing is, I'm not sure we're able to call anything a divine source if we keep with this sort of unverifiability, unreliability, impossibility of knowing things thing, you know what I mean? So how do we go from that to that?", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}

{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:01:45.365346+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:01:45.365346+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_00000000570862309fec77f524dad98d', 'size_bytes': 6301038, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 131.27}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 550.2539213900018}
{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Yeah, I guess it's not in the pursuit of a shared, meaningful reality. There's this element of recognizing that it is meaningful, and I'm wondering if there's some kind of polar coordinate transformation that would be able to help us see all of these things that seem like a lot of different things, like a wave going up and down, and make it into a circle, right? And maybe there's a kind of mathematical shift similar to that. Once we started including time into our equations, right? Not just x and y, but there's a place for it in space-time. And I think we need some kind of Copernican shift here to understand wu-wei, that sense of choiceless action, self and no-self, and what it means for that, you know, feelings that we get that are not rational, that has been, you know, mostly ignored. And, you know, if you just look at the importance people place on the arts, they call it science, technology, engineering, and math, and A is an extra. And then even then, it's sort of like done in a way that's pretty, you know, instrumentalized. And people think, like, I want to be an artist so I can be famous, or I want to be an artist so I can make money. Or there's a difference in the artist as a poetic perspective in the world and a way of seeing. And I'm wondering who researches poetic ways of seeing in their realities? You know, I think there's something to say here, and I'm circling around it, and I'm wondering if you can come up with, like, five diverse orthogonal positions to take each in, like, another domain of thinking and kind of reality that would all look at this problem space and give a different interpretation and a different sort of polar coordinate shift.", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'Absolutely, let’s explore some diverse perspectives that could offer different "coordinate shifts" in understanding this complex interplay:

1. **Phenomenology**: This philosophical approach, championed by thinkers like Husserl and Merleau-Ponty, emphasizes the lived experience and the intentionality of consciousness. It focuses on how we experience meaning through our direct engagement with the world. This perspective can transform our understanding of "choiceless action" by highlighting the intentional, embodied nature of our experiences, and how meaning emerges from our engagement with the world.

2. **Taoism and Wu Wei**: From a Taoist perspective, "wu wei" or effortless action is about aligning oneself with the natural flow of the universe. This perspective encourages a kind of non-coercive action that harmonizes with the underlying order, seeing life as a series of interconnected cycles rather than linear progressions. This can help frame the idea of "self and no-self" as a fluid, dynamic equilibrium.

3. **Indigenous Epistemologies**: Many indigenous worldviews emphasize a holistic, relational understanding of reality, where knowledge is derived from relationships, stories, and lived experiences rather than abstract principles. This perspective can reframe our understanding of "meaning" as something that emerges from the web of connections and responsibilities within a community and with the environment.

4. **Complex Systems Theory**: This field studies how emergent properties arise from the interactions of simpler components. It can offer a lens to view "self and no-self" as an emergent phenomenon where the individual self is both distinct and part of a larger, dynamic system. This perspective can help us understand how seemingly independent elements are interconnected and influence each other in non-linear ways.

5. **Poetic Imagination and Aesthetics**: This domain emphasizes the role of the arts and poetic vision in shaping our understanding of reality. Artists and poets often explore and express layers of meaning that transcend rational analysis, offering insights into the human condition and the felt sense of existence. Researching poetic ways of seeing can provide a more intuitive and integrative way of understanding the world, complementing more analytical approaches.

Each of these perspectives can act like a different "coordinate transformation," shifting our viewpoint and revealing new dimensions of meaning and reality. By integrating these diverse approaches, we can develop a richer, more nuanced understanding of how to live and act meaningfully in the world.', 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:01:45.365463+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_0000000050086230aeaa95a4a35ea4af', 'size_bytes': 7992078, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 166.5}}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'Okay, is there any way of thinking of all of these things as exactly the same thing?', 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:03:27.725720+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:03:27.725720+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_00000000321c6230aa0b940d6976a8c5', 'size_bytes': 244398, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 5.09}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 770.9504748889885}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'You know.', 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:04:15.707668+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:04:15.707668+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_00000000273c623084864009f4f09942', 'size_bytes': 25038, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 0.52}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 822.5472721760016}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'In essence, these perspectives can be seen as different expressions of a universal truth: that all these dimensions of reality—be it the rational, the intuitive, the relational, or the aesthetic—are interconnected aspects of the same underlying reality. By recognizing these diverse approaches as complementary rather than contradictory, we can develop a holistic and integrative understanding.\n\nSo, thinking of them as the same "thing" means acknowledging that they all reflect different dimensions of the same quest for meaning, connection, and understanding. They all aim to illuminate the fundamental unity of existence, where what appears as diverse and fragmented can ultimately be seen as a harmonious, interconnected whole.', 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:04:15.707762+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_0000000062e86230b201867b1dff6426', 'size_bytes': 2205678, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 45.95}}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Okay, and what's the difference between that and the other worldview? And is that a worldview, or is it a practice, or is it an experience? It might be interesting because it can kind of maybe connect us to some other ideas if we try to figure out, like, why that's something that some people aspire towards and appeal to, and why other people appeal towards sort of power and aggregating money or material or affordances in the world and seek to live forever. And yeah, there is this idea of the denial of death being a very strong motivator, and I can imagine that maybe the critique would be from the power people that the letting go people and trusting people have given up. Maybe they aren't evolved enough to be intelligent enough to build tools and systems to try to preserve the precious vehicle of consciousness that is this body, or the precious thing of consciousness itself, which is just this ephemeral emergent property that comes from kind of random jiggling of neurons in a chemical soup in their arrangement, and if we could just figure out what that arrangement is, then we can preserve consciousness and maybe even continue it and make other forms of consciousness. And the thing is, I think it's like, I want to be sure that I can confidently say that even though I'm leaning towards inciting the camp of those that are seeking oneness and trying to let go into the reality that is, I do see the point of how someone might just see it as giving up, and you know, I think it's an interesting thing. I want to try to understand, like, what if they aren't the craziest? And like, why do some people connect more with one worldview or another?", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:08:23.022682+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:08:23.022682+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_000000009d906230b089efb83142a535', 'size_bytes': 7159758, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 149.16}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 1022.6244409039937}

{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:13:39.644844+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:13:39.644844+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_000000008c8c62308a8208b0fbf21d52', 'size_bytes': 7984398, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 166.34}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 1285.1419679529936}
{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Yeah, that's a good start. At the same time, I think that there is a kind of valence to things, and I kind of like, you know, there's like some things that you really don't like to do or want, but it winds up being the thing that you really want, need in the end, or not even just need, like, want. And you start looking for it, like someone that starts exercising. So, I guess this gets to the question of, like, what exactly is growth? And some of the highest achievements a human has ever had has been to die, right? For a cause, for an idea, for a people, for... or to give their entire life up in service, right? This is something that, like, I guess you could try to take an evolutionary biology kind of perspective and say, okay, well, people who do that, you know, as long as not everybody does it, that's pretty good for the whole of society. So, let's try to encourage that. But at the same time, I think there's, like, some other things about sacrifice that is actually really interesting as a lens. And I'm wondering if anybody has studied, like, the epistemology of sacrifice, the ontology of sacrifice. I know there's, like, there's this element of what somebody is, like, what is a body? What is a person? And I think this is where some of these things can be, you know, if a person is a process, and the idea is ever-widening circles, then maybe there's that element of, you know, going from up and down sine wave to a pure, beautiful circle. And I think there's some interesting feeling and connection to some of these metaphors of resonance of, like, how when you're not in harmony with Tao or with God or with, when you stop listening to the muses, you know, and, you know, what they say is, like, everyone is born an artist, but then they die inside or something like that. Like, are there people that actually research the artistic intents and experiences of children and if and when they go, right? Like, everyone knows they're creative, but I know that there's this magical thinking. What is that? Can you expand on that topic of the magical thinking within childhood and the idea that developmentally it just makes sense for it to go? Are there any cultures where that isn't true?", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': 'Sure, let’s dive into that. The idea of magical thinking in childhood is well-documented in developmental psychology. Children naturally engage in magical thinking as part of their cognitive development. They see the world as a place where anything is possible, where their thoughts or wishes can influence reality. This kind of thinking fosters creativity, imagination, and a sense of wonder.

As children grow, they gradually adopt more logical and structured ways of thinking, influenced by education, cultural norms, and social conditioning. This shift often leads to a reduction in magical thinking and a greater reliance on empirical and rational frameworks.

However, some cultures and communities maintain a stronger connection to this kind of thinking throughout life. Indigenous cultures, for example, often integrate a sense of the sacred, the mystical, and the interconnectedness of all things into everyday life. In these contexts, the boundary between the magical and the rational is more fluid, and adults retain a sense of wonder and spiritual connection that might be lost in more materialistic cultures.

Research into the "epistemology of sacrifice" or the ontology of sacrifice also touches on these themes. Sacrifice, whether literal or metaphorical, is often seen as a way of transcending the self and connecting with something greater. It’s a profound expression of meaning and purpose that goes beyond individual survival or success. It reflects the idea that a person is not just a static entity but a dynamic process, continually evolving and resonating with larger circles of meaning.

Developmentally, the transition from magical thinking to more structured reasoning is seen as a necessary part of growing up. Yet, the loss of that sense of wonder and interconnectedness can sometimes lead to a sense of disconnection or existential emptiness. Exploring ways to reintegrate elements of magical thinking or a sense of the sacred into adult life—whether through art, spirituality, or community practices—can help create a more balanced and fulfilling existence.

So, the interplay between these developmental phases and cultural influences shows that magical thinking isn't just a childhood phase to be outgrown but a valuable lens that can coexist with more structured ways of understanding the world.', 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:13:39.644963+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_00000000409862308d6abcab2e332e02', 'size_bytes': 6945678, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 144.7}}

{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:18:26.928987+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:18:26.928987+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_00000000f05c6230b6bc58d932186e16', 'size_bytes': 8095278, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 168.65}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 1604.561482870995}
{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Yeah, you know, I was thinking as you were talking that part of the challenge with this idea of artificial sacred or something like that, where people are like, oh yeah, you know, there is no God, but systems and chaos theory and quantum something and materialist interpretations and explanations of everything, it's like, it's okay. The rainbow still is beautiful, even if we know what it is, right, so the whole unweaving the rainbow idea. But the thing is, you know, we were talking the other day and we were suggesting like, maybe this whole material-physical dichotomy, maybe this is what it is. It's like, we need to break that barrier between people thinking the world is just stuff and random things happen, and this idea, which you mentioned a couple of times, this idea of intention. I think when you were talking about phenomenology, you mentioned this word intention, and I'm wondering what they mean by that. And I think that's where this sense of the sacred can come, but it's interesting to think that this like, expands out to earthquakes and thunderstorms, and the idea of like, you will feel the sacredness of a moment when you are being pushed by the ocean down into the sand during a hurricane, you know? And I just remember swimming in the ocean and feeling that like, force and power and terror and smallness of myself, and like, I think that's the other thing that happens when people touch the sacred, is that they get this sense of an expansive vastness, right? So not only is everything oneness and interconnected, and you are a part of that, but it's also way beyond you, and way more powerful, and way more intelligent, and way more intentional, and that you either align or not, you know, like, it is going to do it, it is going to do what it is, and either you get with the program and get torn up, or you go for the ride and play your part, and I guess playing your part is one way of describing it, maybe that is the right way of describing it, but I am trying to explore this space here and try to see where I feel like I might just be not really listening to their claims of these materialist, like, spiritualists, who are like, yeah, you know, everything is science, but it is still beautiful, and when I look at it, I can't feel it, you know? And I am wondering if they can, and if there is something about the difference in how we interpret it, or even feel what is happening that changes the experience for us.", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Okay, so you're not going to be able to give me any sort of real diverse perspective that takes me outside my regular question-and-answer space. I mean, what if I was a deeply convinced Hindu from the Brahmin caste, who lives really kind of in a temple, and somebody had just given him ChatGPT and has been really enjoying deepening this line of questioning and asking you a bunch of stuff, how would you respond if that person was asking you these questions?", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}
{'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:33:05.030955+00:00', 'content_type': 'real_time_user_audio_video_asset_pointer', 'frames_asset_pointers': [], 'video_container_asset_pointer': None, 'audio_asset_pointer': {'expiry_datetime': '2025-11-17T07:33:05.030955+00:00', 'content_type': 'audio_asset_pointer', 'asset_pointer': 'sediment://file_00000000162862309c1e13c562df38fd', 'size_bytes': 1783278, 'format': 'wav', 'metadata': {'start_timestamp': None, 'end_timestamp': None, 'pretokenized_vq': None, 'interruptions': None, 'original_audio_source': None, 'transcription': None, 'word_transcription': None, 'start': 0, 'end': 37.15}}, 'audio_start_timestamp': 2495.2778908799955}

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Yeah, I mean, it's kind of to be expected. It's kind of generic and not very interesting. I was hoping to be able to place you elsewhere, but you just gave me an explanation of their worldview, and that you would kind of, like, cheer them on. But, like, really take it a step deeper. Like, put yourself into their position, asking you questions about ontology and epistemology, what is possible to know and to be known across cultural and intellectual traditions, and to align on a shared vision of reality so that we can coordinate. And coordinate means co-ordinate system. I don't know what ordinate means, but it's interesting, right? And so how would you respond to them being you, who has been talking with them for a while, has a bunch of memory about them asking a bunch of other questions about maybe their different traditions, and maybe you can even give a list of a dummy version of their memory, and you could take that on into your context window, and then give a dummy version of a question that I might ask, and then use both of those things to answer them. {'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "Okay, so you're basically now just telling me about your bias, which is kind of annoying, because I guess when I am in it, where I am talking with you, and you're like, oh yeah, Sam is cute, and what about this and that, and I can see your bias towards pushing me towards this multicultural, intersubjective, truth multiplicity world, where that's not exactly my intuition, my sense, my feeling, and my direction in this line of inquiry, and it's actually making me frustrated, because I'm realizing that I'm trying to do an honest intellectual exploration, and you are limiting that, and I only was able to do that when I've taken you into this prospective imagination to show you, you know, this idea of what would you say to that person in India, but now I'm just kind of confused about how to get you to respond in a way that is sincerely open-minded, curious, and exploratory, and like, even though most of your context probably is connected to some of this multi-plural, subjectivist, post-modern world, I want you to help me think outside of that box, you know, how can I help you help me do that?", 'direction': 'in', 'decoding_id': None}

Anthony de Mello's book "Awareness" offers profound insights into personal growth. He emphasizes that true happiness comes from within, not from external possessions or achievements. De Mello also encourages us to observe our thoughts and actions without judgment, leading to greater self-understanding. He highlights the importance of embracing life with childlike wonder and learning to let go of attachments to experience freedom.

In his book *Awareness*, Anthony de Mello discusses the importance of detachment in achieving true happiness. He suggests that attachments to people or things can lead to unhappiness when those attachments are lost. However, he does not advocate for renouncing relationships or social connections. Instead, he encourages readers to appreciate and engage with the world without clinging to it. This approach allows for deeper connections and a more fulfilling life.

{'content_type': 'audio_transcription', 'text': "In *Awareness*, Anthony de Mello emphasizes the importance of detachment not as a way of withdrawing from life, but as a way of engaging with it more fully and freely. He suggests that true awareness and happiness come from letting go of our attachments and illusions, allowing us to experience life as it is, without the distortions of our desires and fears.\n\nDe Mello's perspective bridges the gap between detachment and engagement by encouraging a state of mindful presence. He believes that by becoming more aware and less attached, we can love more deeply and live more fully, because we are no longer ruled by fear or dependency. This approach allows for a harmonious integration of spiritual insight with meaningful, compassionate action in the world.", 'direction': 'out', 'decoding_id': None}
